reviewText:
Early Access Review

Oh man, I just found my favourite game.

I've played Terraria, Risk of Rain, Titan Souls, Brouge etc.
In Terraria, the dungeon stays the same difficulty and you always seem to run out of arrows.
In Risk of Rain, the same maps are repeated.
In Titan Souls, Some of the bosses start to seem like chores.
In Brouge (an old ascii rouglike), My highest ever score was floor 10 (out of 26).

Caveblazers gets the best of all of these games and makes gameplay rewarding, thus somehow cramps everything into a small data file that made me forget how to food.

If you like any of the games mentioned above, I highly recomend Caveblazers.
I wish there was a 'hell yes' recomendation option.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Blaze It

Full disclosure: review copy provided by developer/publisher!

I have a question for you, reader: do you enjoy Spelunky, the roguelite darling that captured the hearts and minds of, well, a lot of people? Then have I got good news for you! Claveblazers IS Spelunky... which is pretty much damning Caveblazers with praise. Yes, it's mechanically sound. Yes, it has some interesting little deviations from the Spelunky formula. Yes, there are a lot of interesting additions planned for the full launch.

It is, however,  unabashedly Spelunky Lite in nearly every meaningful way. There's imitation, and then there's Caveblazers.

You play as a tiny man/kid/dude armed with sword and bow, who's heard tell of a legend: find this cave, blaze within, profit. An ornery old man warns you against this, forgetting he's an NPC in a videogame and CAN'T TELL ME WHAT TO DO. He is disregarded, and your adventure begins in earnest.

For Spelunky people this is all familiar territory: you enter a randomly generated vertical dungeon and descend, smashing crates and chests for loot, items, mysterious potions, and treasure, while avoiding traps and killing cave denizens. Variety at the moment is wanting... there's only one trap I've encountered so far (standard spike trap), and you'll slay a lot of the same bats, slimes, and little dudes over and over again.

Treasure is used as a currency for various shrines that can give you all manner of boosts, and there are little blessings sprinkled randomly throughout each dungeon that can provide the same for free.

However, this is a PSEUDO-MUTIPLAYER title, meaning little dudes that look identical to you will spawn on occasion during your descent. I'm... not entirely sure if they're always hostile or not (apparently their behavior is randomized – friendly, enemy, fearful). First playthrough I'm pretty certain the little pseudo-player fella that spawned for me was friendly until I peppered him with too much arrow fire. But after that every single one that spawned hated my guts – fortunately they hate the standard enemies with nearly the same enthusiasm, and they can all kill each other well enough.

These pseudo-players can grab power-ups, items, treasure and weapons just like you so it's critical you stay ahead of them. They also employ a more human-like strategy to ruining (or assisting!) your day, so best kill them or get out of the level as quickly as possible.


It's a cute little game, and I enjoy it. The combat feels good – enemies move fast, and each fatal blow feels impactful. The sounds (music, combat, ambiance) are excellent, the dungeon layouts are interesting, the RNG-y bits are RNG-y... it's just a bit more hollow, and a bit less charming than Spelunky. Now it's Early Access which means they intend to add new weapons and enemies, bosses, a proper endgame, customization – all that good stuff.

I recommend Caveblazers in that it is a fun game that feels complete. Even if they don't finish every planned feature, it's an excellent little game that stands on its own currently. If you have any doubts or wish to see any feature properly implemented and not just hypothetical in hypothetical land, I recommend holding off and seeing how Caveblazers develops.

The game itself controls pretty well, with some glaring issues(for me) - and unfortunately, I read in a few forums that the developer ditched progress on this game, so it's not likely to get fixed.  Here are my issues:

~ It feels like the challenge in this game doesn't come from skill or learning how to get out of situations, it comes down to making do with the things you are denied, as a player - which smells like lazy game design, to me. reviewText:
Early Access Review

Yup - good game.  Must buy at the price.

Combat, RPG elements, and very interesting AI controlled 'players' who compete and sometimes work with you set it apart from the other cave diving games.

Graphics are par for the genre, and it looks nice with some nice pixel art and effects.

Levels contructs are good, has level destruction which is ace.

Looking forward to the future developments, dev seems to have an excellent grasp on AI with taking on such a hard task as emulating players - and succeeding to a very large extent.  I hadnt read about them when I bought it and actually went back into the game page to see if there was some kind of invasion multiplayer muchanic going on.

Really cool.  And less than 5$ devs?  Seriously you should charge more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Rupeck Games have taken the formula that made Derek Yu’s Spelunky one of the most beloved indie games of the past decade and tweaked it to provide gamers their own take on the rogue-like action adventure game. It’s a big ask for any studio let alone one that has never released a game onto Steam before. However, what they have to offer thus far in their early access release has left a positive impression not only on me but all but two of the Steam reviews as of writing.

Most important of all the game is already technically sound. The game play is smooth and thoroughly enjoyable. Nothing feels unfair. The graphics are simplistic but it is easy on the eye and allows you to focus at what is most important while the soundtrack has been carefully chosen to provide for deeper immersion. I quite enjoyed that a point of differentiation is that there are plenty of other cave diggers in these levels with you. It is up to you to discover whether they are friendly, apprehensive or literally out to kill you. Can you work with those that aren’t going to kill you or will you attempt to slaughter them to ensure that everything within the level is yours for the taking? Be mindful, however, that they hit hard and can be every bit as dangerous as the slimes, bats and other enemy minions out there. The developer has done a marvelous job at creating their artificial intelligence to the point where many times they feel every bit as much another human controlled player as artificially controlled. In this respect Rupeck Games label the game a pseudo-multiplayer game. The game takes on rogue-like aspects in that the game features permanent death as well as procedural level generation.

The inventory system is one of my favorite aspects of the game. You’ll find plenty of things out there that can aide in your journey. There are quite a few potions that are named after colors, for example, jade potion.  You likely wont ever be told what they actually do and their effects can have a negative consequence (e.g. causing slowness). Using a bad one at the wrong time can aide in your death so be careful!

The only real downside to the game is that it does not have an end point at this point in development. That is to come. So for those of you who like to have a game that has a certain point of closure you will not yet find that here.  Some may argue that the graphics are a little too simplistic but as I said I found them to be acceptable and others may argue that the game is not original enough but and again I would suggest that they need to look deeper into the game.

At a price tag of $4.99 I would suggest that the game is well worth the investment especially considering the potential of a price increase down the track.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For the current price, Caveblazers is a steal.

While looking a bit bland as of yet, it excels in its responsive controls and the fighting. Throwing everything 'unneccessary' out of its (at least visual) inspiration Spelunky, it adds a quite sophisticated and believable AI in form of 'pseudo-multiplayer', i.e. NPCs that act like other players. Some are murderous b*stards that try to kill you in every way possible, some are just there for the loot and glory, others tend to keep close to you and help out a bit.

What I like a lot about the NPCs is that they feel like being given a gamepad and let loose in the dungeon. Their pathing, jumping, attacking feels just like your own. Sadly, they have no problems whatsoever healing on the fly, whereas the player has to open his inventory with start, possibly navigate to the healing item with the d-pad, hitting A to eat and close his inventory again with start. Some sort of quick-select menu in the HUD that would let you pre-select a bit of meat with the d-pad and just hit a button to actually consume would help a lot.

So what does it have?
- procedural generated levels out of 'level-chunks', starting you at the top of each level with the exit at the bottom, just like Spelunky
- melee and ranged attacks (melee on X, 8-directional shooting with the right thumbstick - which makes jumping (A) and shooting a bit tricky in the beginning)
- consumables: unidentified potions, mostly beneficial with some nasty ones in between, bombs, stun and lightning 'grenades', good selection of swords and bows to find, magic items that usually need to charge up for a while before you can use them, lots of gems and such as currency for the
- shrines that may heal you fully or sell you potions or wands
- quite a selection of blessings in the form of runes that float in the air and you have to jump into them to gain their effect - they freeze you for a bit, so watch out for nasties before getting them

As of now, the game has no story, ending or bosses, it's a fast-paced, difficult score attack game with online leaderboards - which makes the hard NPC 'players' a real asset to the game, I can only hope they do not get nerfed too much after the (forseeable) complaints about their OP-ness.

Again, for 5 bucks it's a steal, just get it.

Peace

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's hard to keep my attention nowadays. I picked up Caveblazers on a whim because I'm one of the few who enjoy, not only early access titles, but bargain kicks by indie developers. With only a couple hours in here, let's recap what I've found:

1) Evolving Early Access title with low risk (+)
2) Bargain at <$5 (+)
3) Replayability that keeps me coming back (+)
4) Unique concept with crazy NPC AI (+)
5) Platformer with controller support (+)
6) Cute retro graphics that even my laptop can crank (+)
7) Lots of unique loot (+)
8) Procedural generation keeps it fresh (+)
9) Satisfying, even in quick doses (+)
10) Just good, solid fun (+)

That's a lot of pluses with a minimal investment. If you're looking for a fresh take on a platfrom roguelike, and you're into having a good time...pick this up!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Can't emphasize enough how fun this game is!
I'm a huge fan of the Spelunky+Roguelike formula; Vagante and Catacomb Kids are among my favourite games ever, and if you enjoy any of these, you'll feel right at home on Caveblazers.
Caveblazers catapults the basic gameplay from Spelunky into a much more chaotic (in a good way!) pacing.
The gameplay flows beautifully: platforming is fluid and fast, combat is dynamic with its inclusion of both melee and ranged capabilities from the get go and tactical thinking is constantly put at test, especially when evading and trying to get the upper hand on AI opponents.
But not only in the basics it really shines. Caveblazers is also pretty detailed when it comes to possibilities (like shooting downwards into wallgrab into walljump into second downward shot), it also features a character progression system without the use of experience points and levels, basing itself entirely into finding special runes which grant you added perks such as double jumps or randomly shooting lighting bolts. While this does break the traditional 'build your character as you desire' sort of philosophy in favor of a more random and unexpected gameplay progression, it helps settle variety and testing your skills in all possible ways feels refreshing.
As of the second patch (which came just a few days after release) the development in Early Access shows promise. Developers are actively looking for suggestions and actually implementing them in an efficient way.
0 bugs so far, as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can say, without a doubt, Caveblazers is shaping up to be the best roguelike platformer I have ever played. I can definitely see it being the comparative game for all others that will follow further into development and release.

I had issues getting a Playstation 4 controller to work with the game so I can only speak for keyboard controls, but even with this minor issue (and the only bug I could find overall) [EDIT: I have been told PS4 controller support will come in the future, not a bug] the controls are incredibly responsive and easy to figure out. You get so drawn into playing the game that each keystroke just feels like a natural extension of yourself. I never expected to be as immersed as I was in the game and this was a major factor towards that.

Graphically the game is sound. I am a huge fan of pixel graphics, but only when they are done properly. And boy, were they done properly here. The animation is deliberate and fluid. Every entity's walk cycle is gorgeous. The particle and lighting effects are beautiful. Personally speaking, I loved the arrow effects that would change with each blessing and bow that you encounter.

Gameplay wise Caveblazers is refreshing. I have never been the biggest fan of a roguelike game in the past, but can typically appreciate them for their merits. This was never the case in this game. I found the challenge to push as far as I could to be more rewarding than in other roguelikes I have enjoyed in the past (See: Dungeon Souls & Hero Siege). Another aspect I noticed keeping me coming back was the joy I got from actually exploring the stage and finding as much loot as I possibly could. Generally speaking, I am not a completionist of this sort, but Caveblazers has such a sense of exploration and discovery driving the gameplay that I simply couldn't help myself.

There is a lot to talk about and experience within Caveblazers, but as I stated before, this is a game about discovery and I'd rather you have a chance to see it for yourself. This is one early access title you do not want to miss out on supporting. Buy this game and buy it today.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

IntroductionPublished and developed by Rupeck Games, Caveblazers is a fast paced roguelike game with randomly generated levels, a vast amount of enemies, items and weapons that you can find whilst you play through each run of this game.

GameplayThe first point to take from Caveblazers is that this game is categorized as a roguelike game. This game is suppose to be difficult and cruel to you throughout the time that you play it. That doesn’t mean, however, that this game isn’t fun. With the increasing difficulty of the game, it is very satisfying to complete just one level through your run, which is what a difficult game should have all together to make the player keep coming back to it. Although I did find that sometimes the game would be way too difficult and it discouraged me to play the game anymore.

With this game being categorized as a roguelike genre of gaming, it does offer the main mechanics that a game of this genre should have. With randomly generated levels, a dungeon crawler feel to it, the difficulty curve that should go at a steady pace and permadeath. Caveblazers does most of this fairly well, with each level being randomly generated it really does add replay value to this game making you come back to play more.

With the starting weapons that you acquire before entering the level, there are several types of attacks. Within the short tutorial that you are given before you enter the first level you are given a sword and bow in order to fight the enemies that are in the levels. The sword has a few functions that you can use, you have your normal slashing from left to right and then you have a upward and downward strike which is rather helpful when you are attacking enemies from above or below. The bow takes more accuracy and precious timing in order to get right, you are going to need to use the bow in order to hit enemies from a distance as just using your sword isn’t always going to work. I found that the key bindings for the bow and arrow a little weird for a weapon that requires accuracy and precious timing. You will need to use the arrow keys in order to aim your bow, therefore being restricted to only eight directions (Up, up left, left, left down etc.). I would of liked the option to be able to use the mouse to be able to aim the bow as this is a much more precious and better to use than the restricted arrow keys.

This game does seem to have a small amount of RPG elements that are implemented into the game, like artifacts that you can collect to increase your character’s stats and be able to progress through the game a little easier. You may encounter these artifacts throughout your runs that will increase your character’s stats, though these will be randomly chosen for you. Some of these artifacts include Knights bleeding, Blessing of Endurance, Volatile blessing and many more that will up your stats of the character that you play as throughout of of the runs.

Throughout your run you will find many items inside of chests and crates that you will have to smash open in order to obtain. These items will become vastly useful as you play through the game and get to the challenging levels. These items could range from upgrades of your weapons, consumables that you can use to heal up, and buff up your character for for the good or bad. Another item you will find a lot is money in chests and crates that you can spend on statues that will help your character.

The enemies AI is rather well played out, and the variety amount of enemies is rather nice. Some of the enemies will attack each other if they come across each one other with the possibility of them killing each other, making it easier for you. While some enemies have the same sort of mechanics as you do, being able to wall jump and hold the same starting weapons you own, there are other types of enemies such as bats, slimes and bandits that will attack you as well.

The soundtrack for this game is superb, it really sets the game up to be a fast paced sort of game that will require accuracy. Upon entering the caves, the music is very well suited to the atmosphere. This combined with the sound effects of each of the attacks and moves that you do are really nice, but I feel like they can sharpen up a bit on them.

With the new enemies that you will come across as you progress through each area there will be new enemies that you will encounter. The graphics of this game are rather nice, as you get through each area you will realize that the areas will change and will look different from the previous one. It does seem that the graphics aren’t as polished as some of them could be. The areas do give off that atmosphere that you are enclosed in a cave and that you are going in deeper into each of the areas.

Pros+ Variety of weapons
+ Nicely designed graphics
+ Varied enemies and nice AI
+ Nice music and sound effects
+ Full controller support

Cons- Bow hasn’t got the option to use mouse to aim
- Game can be a bit too difficult at times
- Sound effects could be worked on a bit

Result / Final thoughtsIn conclusion, Caveblazers is a very fun but difficult roguelike game that requires accuracy and precious timing in order to be able to proceed through each of the levels.There is a nice variety of enemies, items and weapons that you can acquire throughout your runs. Although the bow needs the ability to be more accurate and the game’s sound effects need to be a bit more crisp, the game is very fun and addicting to play.

Rating: 7/10

For more in-depth game reviews for indie and AAA games, be sure to check out the Feed Me Pixels[feedmepixels.com] website.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you want a slightly more detailed review, read the bottom of this review.

Pros:
- Interesting Concept
- Fair variety of items
- Potential for satisfying gameplay
- Nice art style

Cons:
- Floaty movement & combat
- Significant balance issues
- Very bare-bones in terms of features & content (Early Access)
- Perma-death replayability when it's setup like a roguelike (Could be a pro depending  preferences)

This game isn't outright 'bad'. I think there's certainly a fair amount of effort put into the game and the concept seems to be something along the lines of Spelunky meets Vagante, except with the worst parts of each. Granted it's early access so perhaps the developer may make changes in future to make the game more enjoyable, balanced, and rewarding, but for the time being, everything in the game is just.... lacking, to say the least. I certainly hope to one day be able to change this review so that I might recommend this game, but it's gonna take quite a bit of work before I can do that. Either way, with the game the way it is now, I don't feel it's worth the $5.00 investment. There's simply nothing promising enough to really make me feel like I'll get my money's worth.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros
+Potions every game have a different effect. One game you play a pink potion may give you +30 health where as in another game a pink potion might set you alight. This adds to a kind of 'risktaking' factor.
+Random map gen means every game the chests, blessings, exit door, etc will all be in different locations you you essentially have new challenges to face.
+The price is really low for the amount of entertainment you can get.
-------------------------------
Neutral
=The pathfinding system is pretty good in this game for the pseudomultiplayer character guys but for other enemies its pretty lacking. A lot of enemies will try to jump over something to get to you and they will continue to jump in that same place unable to move.
=Add an option to return to the main menu from the death screen. It is kind of annoying to have to start a new run only to exit out.
=Melee range is weird. You can be standing over a chest/pot swinging and still wont be able to break it open.
-------------------------------
Cons
-Ranged weapon combat sucks, which in itself sucks considering how big of a role ranged combat plays in this game. I played this game on keyboard and you can only shoot in 8 directions, cross and diagonally, making some enemies very hard to hit. Please add an option for keyboard users to have the mouse to aim with as it would help a ton.
-Right now this game is a bit shallow in item variation. From blessings to weapons they can get pretty repetitive.
-This one is kind of a silly one but as of right now the player (yourself) and all the pseudomultiplayer guys (AI) have the exact same character model. Nothing wrong with this but in fights of 3+ fighters in the exact same oufit and it can be confusing who you are controlling. Add something to differentiate us from the enemies.
-------------------------------
All in all you are getting a fair amount of content for the price. This game is by no means groundbreaking but at the same time I think it is good enough that you will enjoy playing it if you are a fan of the permadeath/rougelite genre.
I'll also change my review as the game is updated or I think of anything else. Right now i'll give Caveblazers a 7/10.

Early Access Review

I've followed Caveblazers since before it was Caveblazers. The developer, Rupeck created game engines for others to use.

Then one engine evolved into this;

Absolute carnage.

A fun, frantic, violent piece of awesome. From the get go you're thrown into a cave and have to survive. Great fun, works amazing with a controller too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was sitting on the fence about reviewing this game until an update came out yesterday that fixed almost everything I didn't like about it. Now I wholeheartedly recommend it.

Pros:
1. A runthrough takes the perfect amount of time
2. The game in its current state is well worth the price, yet it just came out in early access and is planned to have many content updates.
3. Weapons and blessings make each run feel delightfully different from each other (Almost Isaac levels of different)
4. When you do cool maneuvers to get out of risky situations, you feel awesome. The game controls really well.
5. Most enemies are at just the right threat level.
6. Getting high scores is really satisfying.

Cons:
1. The typical potion system with colored potions having unknown effects is present in this game. Like other roguelikes with this system, potions are identified after being used once, but you can only use those potions on yourself, which, as usual, makes the whole system not worth trying out due to riskiness. It either needs a system where you can throw potions at enemies to identify their effect, or potions need to have mostly positive effects. Isaac's pills would be a good place to look. All pills are either positive or neutral except for 1 pill that deals 1 damage to you.

2. You can't tell how a pseudo-multiplayer enemy feels about you until they shoot the first arrow at you. Since they are by far the scariest potential enemy in the game, they NEED to have different colored shirts or something based on their personality." You cant really exploit them as an interesting game mechanic if you have to hide from every single one you see to not take damage.
"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So far, a really fun roguelike.  A decent amount of variety with the enemies.  Has very similiar gameplay mechanics to Spelunky, which you can obviously see it resembles once you play it.  You start with some grenades, a health pack, a sword and a bow.

You will get upgrades and potions, all of which could either be better or worse than what you have.  The potion's can either help or hurt as well.  You will also find blessings, which upgrade various abilities.  My only con is that there is no real reason to fight the enemies. They never drop coins or gems. There is no xp bar either.  I guess the only real reason to attack them is to build up a charge meter for special items you collect throughout the level.

The graphics are very simplistic.  Nothing cute like Spelunky, but then again, you are paying only $5.  So you get what you pay for.  I think most roguelite/like fans will get some mild enjoyment out of this.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In a nutshell: Spelunky meets Risk of Rain's item system, with faux-multiplayer on top.

Simple gameplay that will not fail to amuse/enrage you and get you hooked in the process.
Variety and replayability come through procedural level generation, and a number of random items and blessings.
The blend of random blessings, items and levels makes each playthrough unique, and the behavior of the AI opponents you will encounter will add another random element - some will be aggressive and gut you like a fish, other cooperative and hang around killing stuff with you.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nEarly Access Review : There has been a large increase in platformer Roguelike and Roguelites recently and for the most part I enjoy most of the ones I have played.  Most of the ones I have played usually start off where all enemys are sigificantly stronger than you to where you are just hoping for a lucky drop to even the playing field. During my few runs in Caveblazers I always felt dying was my own fault and unless I was low health I was not afraid to fight everything. I also never felt overpowered even with my health draining sword and bow that shot out grenades as my health never stayed at full for long. There is a confirmed ending and a boss fight for each area as opposed to just going through seemingly endless floors for no gratification. Nothing in sounds or visuals beyond average that stood out to me you get the idea from the trailer . For the cheap price it is worth it to give it a try and see where it goes as more is added to this title.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tis a really good game, all in all.
my main complaints about it happen to all be things that can and probably will be buffed out during the early access campign.

so the good stuff:
-AI's pretty sophisticated, though occasionally you will see other heroes just standing around, usually they make the combat lively and fun.
-dungeons of dreadmore style item/inventory system with binding of isaac upgrade system makes builds both interactive and choice based but mainly based on rolls of the die since you can see the items beforehand and not waste resources getting to them, equip the weapons/items you want, and not have to deal with much of the level if your build scales well enough to get past most of the enemies at the time due to the fact that there is no build that can just obliterate the competition and continue hoarding items. Taking items is usually a risk and out of your way.
-pause menu doesn't actually pause the game, making inventory management based off of your ability to clear out an area therefore rewarding good play.

bad stuff:
-build veriety consists of range/magic and melee/dying all the time
-really really hard to make a good melee/all around build in this game because of how hard it is to recover from a hit. This is true especially if you're really new to the game and haven't seen all of the end game swords.
-all of the heroes look the same. This is one of those early access things and it'll probably get buffed out soon enough but, blue shirted dudes aren't the best thing to have the hardest enemy in your game by far be sprited as. just sayin.
-other art stuff, I don't know if this is true but the game looks kinda like someone did both the art and the programming and didn't really care how mediocre everything looks. I mean, it's okay, it's not bad by any means but you're going up against tons of amazing games when you're making a game in the roguelite genre.


in the end I suggest you buy it a bit later but buying it now is still a pretty good choice. Afterall I am writing this after like an hour of playtime, there's probably a lot more I'm missing and I can't wait to figure it out.



and to the devs, even though I'm critisizing this game, it's ♥♥♥♥ing great, keep doing what you're doing! I know how hard game dev can be and I feel like people need to hear stuff like this more often.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, especially considering the current low entry cost.

Pros:
+ Great character control: its a pixel perfect dungeon crawler, so there's a warm up period to get them down just as with any title. Combat is challenging and takes practice to get timing down.

+Art fits the genre and looks good in action.

+ Decent number of items currently, though overall they will need to be expanded on a great deal to keep replayability there.

Neutral:
/ Low enemy variety: I think i faced the same enemy spawns from level 10 - 110, jsut with higher HP and stats. We already know that this is being added to.

/ Item diversity: Weapon variety isn't bad at all, but there are standouts in each category that make the other options feel like obvious throw aways. Namely magic items- I found the crystal skull to be the only one worth using as the attack options are just underwhelming.

/ Level variety: Despite being procedural I was able to recognize repeated map layouts/sections during the long run I completed. Casual gamers may never notice- I certainly did.

Cons:
- Inventory system: It's just plain terrible in its current implementation and without question the games biggest negative. My advice would be to rebind the Inventory button to either R1 or L1- it allows more natural finger movements during combat meaning you can access your inventory while moving and fighting- thats not possible bound to the Back key. With this method I was able to hit the keys so fast the UI didnt even pop up on screen meaning i could use something like 6-10 heal items a second.

- Current replayability: I made it to floor 110 on my 3rd run and only stopped cause I was 6 hours in and once you make it that far you're never gonna die anyways, you're literally just playing until your controller falls apart.

- The Faux player Ai mechanic: it was interesting the first 5 minutes, after that it became obvious its a just player trolling feature. regardless of all the things they could possibly do with/to your char- in the end they just attack you and cause you headaches. I rather enjoyed reaching the point they would just die immediately upon spawning, around floor 60 or so I think.


This is a really nice game, if you enjoy the genre this one is a must buy considering its still in early dev time- it should only get better from here.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis game fills the I need to kill 10-15m" niche for me. I liked Spelunky but in that you can't explore a level as much as you want
date: there is a bit of a time limit. My main suggestion for this game would be an easy (or easier) mode
recommended: as I'm very casual. I also think the bow would be better if you could fire in more than the cardinal 8 directions.\n\nExcellent casual game for $4.99"

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nGreat roguelike platformer, the controls are a bit funky but easy to get used to. 10/10 stars.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

after recently buying this game and playing for a solid 5 hours worth heres what i can say

Pros
- Just how a rogue like game should be, fun, lots of items and fairly challenging
- Simple yet great graphics
- Very addicting and hard to put down
- Controller adaptable (i find it muchy easier to play games with a controller)
- Smart AI player's which will either try to hurt you or just leave you be

Cons
- game crashes often saying something like fatal error - Out of memory" which is there is no way it could be for my computer i have way much higher specs than required so PLEASE FIX THIS! it is very annoying when im having a perfect run and boom.. the game crashes
- lags quite a lot when using the ankh (not sure if spelt that right) it usually causes game to crash
- the hit boxes need a slight change ive hit enemies dead on sometimes they wont take damage
- spikes do way too much damage considering the enemies that are in the game for exampel the exploding blue circle that launchs itself at you im pretty sure an explosion should be doing more damage than spikes are i advise adding maybe a height based damage mechanic for the spikes this will make it more fair especially for players who are just trying to get around them.

all in all its a great game to play but it needs to fix these bugs and problems that are in the game. i know its in early access so i hope to see as i play the game that those problems are fixed and maybe some more features are added like character customizing
date:
unlockable characters with different start weapons!

for now i reccomend playing this game but just be wary of the bugs/problems that have been noted above!

Great work producers i hope to see this game in a better state i will keep updating this review as i play this game!"
